sub_topic: The Poincaré map and its use in studying chaotic systems
message_1: Suppose we have a chaotic system with a Poincaré section defined by the iterative equation x<sub>n+1</sub> = 2x<sub>n</sub> (mod 1) for all n>=0. If the initial condition is x<sub>0</sub> = 0.1, what is the value of x<sub>10</sub> (correct to two decimal places)?
message_2:
We can find the value of x<sub>10</sub> by iterating the equation 10 times, starting with x<sub>0</sub> = 0.1.

x<sub>1</sub> = 2 * 0.1 (mod 1) = 0.2
x<sub>2</sub> = 2 * 0.2 (mod 1) = 0.4
x<sub>3</sub> = 2 * 0.4 (mod 1) = 0.8
x<sub>4</sub> = 2 * 0.8 (mod 1) = 1.6 (mod 1) = 0.6
x<sub>5</sub> = 2 * 0.6 (mod 1) = 1.2 (mod 1) = 0.2
x<sub>6</sub> = 2 * 0.2 (mod 1) = 0.4
x<sub>7</sub> = 2 * 0.4 (mod 1) = 0.8
x<sub>8</sub> = 2 * 0.8 (mod 1) = 1.6 (mod 1) = 0.6
x<sub>9</sub> = 2 * 0.6 (mod 1) = 1.2 (mod 1) = 0.2
x<sub>10</sub> = 2 * 0.2 (mod 1) = 0.4

So, x<sub>10</sub> = 0.4 (correct to two decimal places).
